categories.recommendationText:
Recommended models are standout choices with high scores. They include CR Best Buys, which offer exceptional value. When narrowing your choices among mattresses, weigh performance, features, price and attributes that matter to you, such as ease of movement and maintaining warmth.

Now CR is bringing our independent research, testing and recommendations to you, when and where you shop.  Learn more about CR Recommended.

ownerSatisfaction.infoText: Owner satisfaction is based on members’ average overall satisfaction rating for their mattress brand and type on a scale from completely satisfied to completely dissatisfied.

categories.surveyDescription: Ratings are based on the Consumer Reports’ 2020 Winter Survey of 4,405 CR members reporting on their mattress purchases made in 2019 and the first quarter of 2020. Reader Score represents members’ overall satisfaction with their retail experience. If all respondents are “completely satisfied” with a particular store, the reader score would be 100; a score of 80 indicates that respondents are “very satisfied” on average; 60, “fairly well satisfied.” Differences of less than 5 points are not meaningful. All other attributes listed under Survey Results reflect average scores on a scale from “very poor” to “excellent.” Price is a rating of the price paid for the mattresses. Selection refers to the range of available mattress brands or models. Sales Service refers to the quality of service from sales help. Customer Support is indicative of the quality of customer support for things such as phone service and shipping information. Floor Model Cleanliness specifies the cleanliness of the mattresses in the store showroom. On-Time Delivery refers to the timeliness of the mattress delivery service. Delivery Quality is indicative of the quality of the mattress delivery service. Ratings are based on the experiences of CR members, who may not be representative of the general US population. Dashes (“-“) indicate insufficient sample sizes for analysis or that an attribute is not applicable to a particular store.

models.overallScoreDescription: Based mainly on side and back sleeper support, durability, and stability; displayed score is out of a total of 100 points.
models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: This reasonably priced hybrid mattress-in-a-box combines innersprings and layers of foam. The result is an impressive bed, especially for back sleepers. Most side sleepers should be pleased as well. It’s highly stable, keeping vibrations to a minimum. With a rating of 7 out of 10, this model is on the firm side. And its durability, while rated Very Good, falls short of the top ratings found on many competitors.

attributes.name: Petite side sleeper
attributes.description: Sleepers small in both height and weight.

attributes.name: Average side sleeper
attributes.description: An average of both the petite and large scores that applies to many people.

attributes.name: Type
attributes.description: Indicates the main composition of the mattress, such as innerspring or memory foam. Some so-called "hybrid" innersprings include one or more levels of foam on top.

attributes.name: Dimensions LxWxH
attributes.description: The mattress's dimensions, length by width by height, in inches.

attributes.name: Latex foam
attributes.description: An alternative to memory foam.

attributes.name: Gel-infused foam
attributes.description: A layer of foam infused with gel, which is claimed to make you feel cooler in bed, especially with memory foam.

attributes.name: Resists bounciness
attributes.description: Indicates whether the mattress can absorb impacts, minimizing the bouncy feeling you might encounter while changing sleep position.

attributes.name: Eases movement
attributes.description: Indicates whether the mattress has enough resilience to allow easy changes in sleep position.

attributes.name: Grips
attributes.description: Helpful when handling the mattress.

attributes.name: Retains warmth
attributes.description: Some mattresses are more insulating than others and trap body heat, making you feel warmer.

attributes.name: Large/Tall side sleeper
attributes.description: Side sleepers who are above 6 ft 2 inches tall and/or 220 pounds.

attributes.name: Petite back sleeper
attributes.description: Sleepers small in both height and weight.

attributes.name: Average back sleeper
attributes.description: An average of both the petite and large scores that applies to many people.

attributes.name: Large/Tall back sleeper
attributes.description: Back sleepers who are above 6 ft 2 inches tall, and/or 220 pounds.

attributes.name: Durability
attributes.description: Our analysis of how well a mattress maintains its original shape, height, firmness, and side/back sleeping support after 8 years of simulated use.

attributes.name: Stabilization
attributes.description: A measure of how much vibration is transmitted across the mattress; for memory- and latex-foam mattresses, higher scores indicate ease of changing sleep position.

attributes.name: Firmness rating
attributes.description: Indicates how firm a mattress is on our scale from 1 to 10, where 1 is very soft and 10 is very firm.

attributes.name: Adjustable frame
attributes.description: Adjustable bed frames will allow the head and foot sections to be raised and lowered independently. Note: Some manufacturer's beds will only be compatible with their own adjustable bed frames.

attributes.name: Mattress-in-a-box
attributes.description: The mattress will be delivered to your door compressed and rolled into a box to make it more manageable. Some boxes will be approximately 42 inches tall, 20 inches wide and 20 inches deep and can weigh between 60 and 120 pounds.

models.overallScoreDescription: Based mainly on side and back sleeper support, durability, and stability; displayed score is out of a total of 100 points.
models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: With an Excellent rating for durability, this low-priced foam mattress should hold up well. But not all sleepers can expect top-notch support. Where this model really runs into trouble is with stability, with is rated just Fair. That means a higher risk of a sleeper feeling a partner’s every move. With a firmness rating of 2 out of 10, it’s soft, and it doesn’t make shifting positions easy.

models.overallScoreDescription: Based mainly on side and back sleeper support, durability, and stability; displayed score is out of a total of 100 points.
models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: This mattress-in-a-box combines innersprings and foam layers with mixed results. The support is Very Good for petites and average-sized back sleepers, but merely good for all others. The durability is outstanding, but the stability is middle-of-the-road, and the mattress doesn’t make it easy for sleepers to change positions. It was also found to retain body heat, making sleepers feel warmer at night.

models.overallScoreDescription: Based mainly on side and back sleeper support, durability, and stability; displayed score is out of a total of 100 points.
models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: This very soft innerspring and latex foam mattress holds up well over time, with no noticeable changes in performance over eight years of simulated use. And it does a Very Good job at muting vibrations from traveling across the bed. But the support is disappointing for all but petite side sleepers, and it’s especially problematic for back sleepers, garnering a Poor rating for large/tall back sleepers.

models.overallScoreDescription: Based mainly on side and back sleeper support, durability, and stability; displayed score is out of a total of 100 points.
models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: This low-priced mattress boasts first-rate durability, with only minor changes in firmness, shape, height, and support over eight years of simulated use. And it mutes vibrations well. But the support is all over the map: no better than average for side sleepers, impressive for many back sleepers, but only Fair for large/tall back sleepers. And it doesn’t do well at conforming to various body shapes.

models.overallScoreDescription: Based mainly on side and back sleeper support, durability, and stability; displayed score is out of a total of 100 points.
models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: When it comes to back and spine support, it pays to be petite or average-sized with this foam mattress-in-a-box. For large and tall sleepers, the support is so-so. Durability is rated Excellent, with no noticeable sagging, softening, or other damage in eight years of simulated use. With just average stability, sleepers may feel a partner’s jostling. And this model doesn’t make shifting sleeping positions easy.

models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: This highly rated, bed-in-a-box organic mattress stands out on almost every count. For all but petite side sleepers, it offers Excellent support. In CR’s durability tests, it hits it out of the park, displaying no noticeable changes in performance after eight years of simulated use. The weak spot? Stability is middle-of-the-pack, which could mean some bouncing as a fellow sleeper shifts positions.

expertReview.bottomLine: This Avocado pillow-top model adds 2 inches to the profile of the lower-priced Avocado Green mattress and shares that model’s top-notch durability and middling stability. In CR’s tests, support for almost all types of sleepers was rated Very Good (large and tall back sleepers will find so-so support), but that’s a notch below the original Avocado’s first-rate ratings. Another difference: This pillow-top model retains heat, offering you a toastier slumber.

expertReview.bottomLine: This mattress-in-a-box adds layers of foam to innersprings, including gel-infused foam for cooling. The results are mixed. The support for back sleepers and petite side sleepers is merely average. For all other side sleepers, it’s rated Very Good. Despite the name, a firmness rating of 2 out of 10 makes this model softer than most. The 15-inch height means deep-pocket fitted sheet are likely needed.

expertReview.bottomLine: For everyone except large and tall sleepers, this foam mattress delivers, with top-notch support whether you sleep on your side or back. For large/tall sleepers, though, the support is just so-so. This firm mattress is very stable and rates Excellent for durability, showing little change in performance over eight years of simulated use. This model tends to trap body heat, helping to keep sleepers warm all night.

expertReview.bottomLine: Whether or not you take to this durable, well-priced foam mattress may hinge on how you sleep: on your back or side? For side sleepers, spinal support is Very Good. But support for back sleepers is so-so, even below average for those who are large or tall. Despite the name, CR finds that this model traps body heat. The 14-inch height may mean buying deep-pocket fitted sheets.

expertReview.bottomLine: The verdict on this hybrid foam and innerspring mattress comes down to sleep position. For side sleepers, support is rated Very Good, but for most back sleepers, it’s just average (petite back sleepers do better). This model is highly stable, and durability is top-notch. In eight years of simulated use, there’s no noticeable sagging, softening, or other damage. The 15-inch height means you’ll need deep-pocket fitted sheets.

And most side sleepers will enjoy impressive support. (Large and tall side sleepers are the exception.) This model is highly stable, and the durability is first-rate, with no discernible sagging, softening, or other damage over eight years of simulated use. The 12-inch height means no need for deep-pocket fitted sheets.

models.modelName: Silver BRS900-TSS Medium Firm Tight Top
models.overallScoreDescription: Based mainly on side and back sleeper support, durability, and stability; displayed score is out of a total of 100 points.
models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: This moderately priced mattress offers most sleepers very good support, though the verdict is mixed for anyone who is large or tall: The support rates Excellent for those who sleep on their backs but no better than average for side sleepers. Otherwise, durability is first-rate, with little in the way of sagging, softening, or other damage in eight years of simulated use. And this model is highly stable, keeping vibrations to a minimum.

models.overallScoreDescription: Based mainly on side and back sleeper support, durability, and stability; displayed score is out of a total of 100 points.
models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: This innerspring model, while highly durable and stable, falls short on a key measure: support, which is rated Very Good for petite back sleepers but just average (or worse) for everyone else. A layer of gel-infused foam is designed to keep sleepers cool, but in CR’s tests this model was found to retain heat, which can make sleepers feel warm. The 15-inch height means you’ll need deep-pocket fitted sheets.

models.overallScoreDescription: Based mainly on side and back sleeper support, durability, and stability; displayed score is out of a total of 100 points.
models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: With a BedGear model, buyers can customize the mattress for desired support, even personalizing each side of the bed. This tested model performs quite well, providing most sleepers with support that rates Very Good (for large/tall side sleepers, it’s just average). Durability can’t be beat, and the mattress is highly stable, so one sleeper’s tossing and turning shouldn’t travel far across the bed.

models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: This memory foam mattress provides top-notch support for almost every size and type of sleeper (back and side). The only group that isn’t as well-served are large and tall side sleepers: In CR’s test, their support was rated Good, or no better than average. The mattress’s 3-inch top layer of gel-infused foam supposedly keeps sleepers cool, though our tests were inconclusive. This model gets top scores for stability.

expertReview.bottomLine: When it comes to back and spine support, this innerspring mattress-in-a-box comes through only for a minority of sleepers. Support is rated Very Good for petite and average-sized side sleepers, but subpar for large/tall back sleepers and just average for the rest. Durability is top-notch. In CR’s tests this “medium” model gets a firmness rating of 2 out of 10, putting it on the soft side.

expertReview.bottomLine: This innerspring mattress topped with gel-infused foam delivers Excellent durability and impressive stability. But the support is disappointing. For side sleepers of all sizes, the spine support is no better than average. For back sleepers, support ranges from so-so for petites to Poor for large/tall sleepers. This mattress tends to retain heat, which can make sleepers feel warmer.

expertReview.bottomLine: Casper’s signature mattress-in-a-box serves all sizes and styles of sleepers well. Back sleepers, who can look forward to excellent support, should be especially pleased. This model’s durability is first-rate, with little in the way of sagging, softening, or other damage over eight years of simulated use. Stability, though, is merely average, and, like many foam mattresses, this model doesn’t make shifting sleep positions especially easy.

expertReview.bottomLine: Back sleepers have a lot to like about this innerspring, but you might be less satisfied when you roll onto your side. With a latex-foam topping, the mattress is rated Excellent at supporting the curve of the spine for back sleepers— and very good at keeping side sleepers' spines horizontal. The mattress came out fine after eight years of simulated use, and it was top-notch at minimizing bouncing from across the bed. A 14-inch height may call for deep-pocket fitted sheets.

models.overallScoreDescription: Based mainly on side and back sleeper support, durability, and stability; displayed score is out of a total of 100 points.
models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: Combining innersprings with layers of natural latex foam, this mattress gets the job done. For nearly every size and style of sleeper, the support is impressive (for large and tall side sleepers, it’s just average). Durability is rated Excellent. First-rate stability means vibrations from one partner’s movements shouldn’t travel far, and shifting positions is easy. With a firmness rating of 3 out of 10, it’s on the soft side.

expertReview.bottomLine: This pillow-top mattress performs well overall and is among the best innersprings at supporting the curve of the spine for back sleepers. But side sleepers might be less satisfied. The mattress came out fine after eight years of simulated use, rating Excellent for durability, and was top-notch at muting vibrations, meaning little bouncing from across the bed. It measures 13 inches high, so you might need deep-pocket fitted sheets.

expertReview.bottomLine: This foam mattress-in-a-box provides very good back and side support for all sizes of sleepers, and the durability is top-notch. Trouble is, this model earns a subpar Fair rating for stabilization, which means it doesn’t dampen vibrations especially well, a potential problem for couples. And shifting sleep positions isn’t easy. With a height of 14 inches, deep-pocket fitted sheets may be needed.

expertReview.bottomLine: The price on this innerspring mattress is hard to beat, the durability is Excellent, and for side sleepers the spine support is fine. But the good news ends there. For back sleepers, the support ranges from so-so to abysmal. And when it comes to muting vibrations from traveling across the bed, this model is no better than average. With a firmness rating of 2 out of 10, it’s very soft.

expertReview.bottomLine: This low-priced innerspring mattress topped with gel-infused foam comes up short. In CR’s tests, the support ranges from so-so to awful for most (only large/tall side sleepers do better). A firmness rating of 2 out of 10 means it’s quite soft. On the plus side, the durability is Excellent and it’s highly stable. And the 12-inch height means no need for deep-pocket fitted sheets.

expertReview.bottomLine: This memory foam mattress is solid but not a standout. Where it matters most, the results are mixed: impressive support for petites and average-sized back sleepers, no better than average for the rest. Durability is Very Good, with only minor changes in height, firmness, shape, and support over eight years of simulated use. Stability, though, is just average, so sleepers may feel vibrations across the bed.

expertReview.bottomLine: One of the more reasonably priced models, this model doesn’t make value-conscious sleepers sacrifice a good night’s sleep. A softer mattress that scores equally well for back and side support, it has a surface that conforms to many body shapes. It’s also fairly stable, enabling sleepers to easily change positions and dampening vibrations when they do. It came out well after eight years of simulated use, scoring Excellent for durability.

expertReview.bottomLine: This reasonably priced innerspring mattress topped with foam performs well for all side sleepers, earning a Very Good rating for support. But it’s a middle-of-the-road choice for average-sized and large and tall back sleepers. First-rate stability means vibrations don’t travel far, a boon for couples when one partner tosses and turns. With a firmness rating of 3 out of 10, it tends to be soft.

models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: This mattress-in-a-box combines innersprings with a foam layer, with mixed results. For most back sleepers, support earns Very Good ratings (less so for large and tall folks), but side sleepers can do better elsewhere. Still, it’s highly stable, and durability is first-rate. A firmness rating of 2 out of 10 puts it on the soft side. The 15-inch height means deep-pocket fitted sheets are a must.

expertReview.bottomLine: This high-end Swedish brand boasts a host of innovations: steel springs that move with you, a replaceable top pad, and more. The upshot? In CR’s tests, the mattress came through with impressive support: Excellent for large/tall side sleepers and Very Good for most others. It’s durable and conforms to most bodies well, though stability is no better than average. Note: At 178 pounds, it’s far heavier than your typical queen.

expertReview.bottomLine: The price of this foam and innerspring mattress may catch your eye, but the overall so-so support should probably have you looking elsewhere. And for large/tall back sleepers, the support is even worse. On the plus side, it’s highly stable and durable, with only minor changes in performance over eight years of simulated use. With a height of 15 inches, you’ll probably need deep-pocket fitted sheets.

expertReview.bottomLine: With this affordable foam mattress-in-a-box, it pays to be a back sleeper. That group can expect support that's rated Very Good. Side sleepers will do better elsewhere. Still, the durability is top-notch, with no noticeable changes in performance over eight years of simulated use. It’s highly stable, and sleepers shouldn’t have trouble switching positions. This model tends to retain heat, which can make sleepers feel warm.

expertReview.bottomLine: Mattress shoppers who come to Essentia for the organic materials won’t be disappointed in the performance of the company’s natural rubber latex-based foam: In CR's tests, this mattress-in-a-box does a Very Good job (or better) of supporting back and side sleepers, and gets Excellent scores for durability and stability, so one partner’s tossing and turning shouldn’t jostle the other sleeper. The 8-inch height means no shopping for new deep-pocket fitted sheets.

expertReview.bottomLine: True to its name, the mattress is among the firmest in its category, with a firmness rating of 7 out of 10. Its surface conforms to most body shapes well, and its breathability is better than average, potentially reducing perspiration. Large/tall back sleepers, ill-served by many mattresses, can find Excellent support with this model. For all others, the support is superb. Durability and stability are both impressive as well.

expertReview.bottomLine: With layers of natural latex and gel-infused foam topping innersprings, this mattress provides impressive support for all types of sleepers. For petite sleepers, it’s excellent. The same goes for durability. In eight years of simulated use, this model shows little sign of sagging, softening, or other damage. A high stability score means the mattress keeps vibrations to a minimum. With a height of 15 inches, deep-pocket fitted sheets are a must.

expertReview.bottomLine: This moderately priced foam mattress-in-a-box supports petite to large and tall back and side sleepers impressively, resists bounciness, and is resilient enough to allow sleepers to change position easily. Its 2-inch layer of gel-infused memory foam is claimed to keep sleepers cool. The mattress is firm for sure, scoring 7 out of 10 in CR’s firmness tests, and the durability is Excellent.

expertReview.bottomLine: The GhostBed Luxe is 2 inches thicker than its lower-priced sibling, the GhostBed. In CR’s tests, both were found to be durable and stable, but the Luxe actually lags in certain ways. Though it offers Very Good support for petite and average sleepers, the support for large and tall sleepers is just so-so. Also, it was found to be less firm than the basic GhostBed.

expertReview.bottomLine: This innerspring mattress-in-a-box should please sleepers of almost every stripe. For all but large and tall back sleepers, the support is rated Very Good. Durability is top-notch, with no noticeable changes in performance over eight years of simulated use. Stability is no better than average, though, and switching sleep positions isn’t easy with this model. The 14-inch height means deep-pocket fitted sheets may be needed.

models.overallScoreDescription: Based mainly on side and back sleeper support, durability, and stability; displayed score is out of a total of 100 points.
models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: The verdict on this innerspring model comes down to sleep style. Support for back sleepers of all sizes earns Excellent ratings. But it’s merely average for petite and average-sized side sleepers. (Large and tall ones fare better.) It’s highly stable, so sleepers shouldn’t feel many vibrations from a partner’s tossing and turning. Durability is first-rate, so softening, sagging, and other damage shouldn’t be a problem in the years ahead.

models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: This soft innerspring mattress topped with memory foam does a fine job at supporting side sleepers, and the durability is Excellent, with no noticeable changes in performance over eight years of simulated use. But back sleepers should look elsewhere: Their support is subpar. It is not compatible with bed frames that allow you to adjust the head and foot sections independently. The 17-inch height means there’s no avoiding deep-pocket fitted sheets.

models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: This latex foam mattress is well-priced, but its performance leaves something to be desired. For all but petite sleepers, the support is only so-so. At 7 inches high, it’s especially thin. On the plus side, durability is Very Good, with only minor changes in performance after eight years of simulated use. Like most foam mattresses, it relays few vibrations from one side of the bed to the other.

models.overallScoreDescription: Based mainly on side and back sleeper support, durability, and stability; displayed score is out of a total of 100 points.
models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: With this low-priced model, you won’t sacrifice durability or stability. In eight years of simulated use, it shows only small changes in performance. It mutes vibrations well, so one sleeper’s shifting need not keep a partner awake. In all-important back and spine support, though, it’s inconsistent: Very Good for some, so-so for others. With a firmness rating of 7 out of 10, it’s among the firmer foam models.

models.overallScoreDescription: Based mainly on side and back sleeper support, durability, and stability; displayed score is out of a total of 100 points.
models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: Consumer Reports did not test this model, but we expect it to perform much like the very similar Intellibed Posture Perfect. Both are constructed with a unique nontoxic gel matrix. The tested model excels for its durability and offers side sleepers fine support (less so for most back sleepers). But where it falters is in stability, doing just a Fair job at minimizing the vibrations that can travel across the bed when one bed partner moves around.

expertReview.bottomLine: Side sleepers of all sizes are well-served by this innerspring mattress topped with gel-infused and memory foam. Their spine support rates Very Good. But most back sleepers can find better support elsewhere. Durability and stability are both top-notch. Scoring a 3 out of 10 in CR’s firmness tests, this model is on the softer side. And it is not compatible with bed frames that allow you to adjust the head and foot sections up and down independently.

models.overallScoreDescription: Based mainly on side and back sleeper support, durability, and stability; displayed score is out of a total of 100 points.
models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: Side sleepers will do just fine with this gel-infused foam and innerspring mattress. For large/tall side sleepers, the Excellent support is hard to beat. Back sleepers can do better elsewhere. The durability and stability are above average, and the mattress conforms well to various body shapes. It is not compatible with bed frames that allow you to adjust the head and foot sections independently. The 14-inch height may require deep-pocket fitted sheets.

models.overallScoreDescription: Based mainly on side and back sleeper support, durability, and stability; displayed score is out of a total of 100 points.
models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: This foam mattress-in-a-box delivers mixed results: first-rate support for petite and average-sized sleepers, but for large and tall sleepers, support is merely average. Durability is rated Excellent, with no noticeable changes in performance over eight years of simulated use, and it’s highly stable, which should limit how much vibrations travel. Still, this model doesn’t make shifting positions easy. Plus, it tends to retain body heat.

models.overallScoreDescription: Based mainly on side and back sleeper support, durability, and stability; displayed score is out of a total of 100 points.
models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: This innerspring mattress-in-a-box sports a reasonable price and rates Excellent for durability. But support is no better than average for almost all sleepers (petite side sleepers are the only ones that fare better). With a firmness rating of 2 out of 10, it’s soft. The stability is so-so, and the mattress doesn’t make it easy to shift positions. Its gel-infused foam is designed to keep sleepers cool.

attributes.description: Back sleepers who are above 6 ft 2 inches tall, and/or 220 pounds.

attributes.name: Durability
attributes.description: Our analysis of how well a mattress maintains its original shape, height, firmness, and side/back sleeping support after 8 years of simulated use.

attributes.name: Stabilization
attributes.description: A measure of how much vibration is transmitted across the mattress; for memory- and latex-foam mattresses, higher scores indicate ease of changing sleep position.

attributes.name: Firmness rating
attributes.description: Indicates how firm a mattress is on our scale from 1 to 10, where 1 is very soft and 10 is very firm.

attributes.name: Adjustable frame
attributes.description: Adjustable bed frames will allow the head and foot sections to be raised and lowered independently. Note: Some manufacturer's beds will only be compatible with their own adjustable bed frames.

attributes.name: Mattress-in-a-box
attributes.description: The mattress will be delivered to your door compressed and rolled into a box to make it more manageable. Some boxes will be approximately 42 inches tall, 20 inches wide and 20 inches deep and can weigh between 60 and 120 pounds.

models.overallScoreDescription: Based mainly on side and back sleeper support, durability, and stability; displayed score is out of a total of 100 points.
models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: Among the more affordable bed-in-a-box foam mattresses, the Lull performs with distinction, offering Excellent support for petite back sleepers and impressive support for most others (only large and tall side sleepers may find the support so-so). It adds a layer of gel-infused memory foam, supposedly for coolness. However, in CR's tests the mattress didn’t make it easy for sleepers to change positions.

models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: This Luxi foam mattress is very similar to the more highly rated “Soft” model in the line (in CR’s tests, the firmness ratings are almost the same, with this Medium Firm version coming in a tad softer). The durability is first-rate, and stability is impressive. Though both models offer side sleepers Very Good support, this mattress is worse for back sleepers, delivering so-so support across the board.

models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: Like the other Luxi foam models rated by CR—the Luxi Soft and Luxi Medium Firm—this mattress boasts first-rate durability, impressive support for side sleepers, and Very Good stability. Where it diverges is in its support for back sleepers, which scores a below-average Fair. Shoppers will do better with softer Luxi models, though in CR’s firmness tests this Firm model is rated a relatively soft 3 out of 10.

models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: This latex foam mattress serves side sleepers well, delivering Very Good spine support, but not all back sleepers can count on such top-notch support. The durability is first-class, with only minor sagging, softening, or other damage after eight years of simulated use. And this model is highly stable, keeping vibrations from a partner’s tossing and turning to a minimum, and it conforms well to various body shapes.

models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: This innerspring model stands out for fine back and side support for just about every sleeper (for petite back sleepers, it’s merely average). And it is highly stable. The durability, though very good, falls short of the top-notch performance found on many highly rated models. Despite the name, in CR’s tests this model gets a firmness rating of 3 out of 10, which is on the soft side.

expertReview.bottomLine: This innerspring and foam mattress boasts excellent durability, with little in the way of sagging, softening, and other damage over eight years of simulated use. But that’s the high point. The back and side support it provides is no better than average; same for stability. A firmness rating of 3 out of 10 puts it on the soft side.

comfort.infoText: Comfort is based on members’ average comfort rating for their mattress brand and type on a scale from excellent to very poor.

models.overallScoreDescription: Based mainly on side and back sleeper support, durability, and stability; displayed score is out of a total of 100 points.
models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: Back sleepers are more likely to warm to this mattress-in-a-box than side sleepers are. The support is Very Good for average and large/tall back sleepers (and even better for petites), but most side sleepers will get middling spine support. The durability is Excellent, with very little change in performance over time, and the stability is Very Good. In CR’s tests, the mattress was found to retain warmth.

attributes.name: Petite side sleeper
attributes.description: Sleepers small in both height and weight.

attributes.name: Average side sleeper
attributes.description: An average of both the petite and large scores that applies to many people.

attributes.name: Type
attributes.description: Indicates the main composition of the mattress, such as innerspring or memory foam. Some so-called "hybrid" innersprings include one or more levels of foam on top.

attributes.name: Dimensions LxWxH
attributes.description: The mattress's dimensions, length by width by height, in inches.

attributes.name: Latex foam
attributes.description: An alternative to memory foam.

attributes.name: Gel-infused foam
attributes.description: A layer of foam infused with gel, which is claimed to make you feel cooler in bed, especially with memory foam.

attributes.name: Resists bounciness
attributes.description: Indicates whether the mattress can absorb impacts, minimizing the bouncy feeling you might encounter while changing sleep position.

attributes.name: Eases movement
attributes.description: Indicates whether the mattress has enough resilience to allow easy changes in sleep position.

attributes.name: Grips
attributes.description: Helpful when handling the mattress.

attributes.name: Retains warmth
attributes.description: Some mattresses are more insulating than others and trap body heat, making you feel warmer.

attributes.name: Large/Tall side sleeper
attributes.description: Side sleepers who are above 6 ft 2 inches tall and/or 220 pounds.

attributes.name: Petite back sleeper
attributes.description: Sleepers small in both height and weight.

attributes.name: Average back sleeper
attributes.description: An average of both the petite and large scores that applies to many people.

attributes.name: Large/Tall back sleeper
attributes.description: Back sleepers who are above 6 ft 2 inches tall, and/or 220 pounds.

attributes.name: Durability
attributes.description: Our analysis of how well a mattress maintains its original shape, height, firmness, and side/back sleeping support after 8 years of simulated use.

attributes.name: Stabilization
attributes.description: A measure of how much vibration is transmitted across the mattress; for memory- and latex-foam mattresses, higher scores indicate ease of changing sleep position.

attributes.name: Firmness rating
attributes.description: Indicates how firm a mattress is on our scale from 1 to 10, where 1 is very soft and 10 is very firm.

attributes.name: Adjustable frame
attributes.description: Adjustable bed frames will allow the head and foot sections to be raised and lowered independently. Note: Some manufacturer's beds will only be compatible with their own adjustable bed frames.

attributes.name: Mattress-in-a-box
attributes.description: The mattress will be delivered to your door compressed and rolled into a box to make it more manageable. Some boxes will be approximately 42 inches tall, 20 inches wide and 20 inches deep and can weigh between 60 and 120 pounds.

Based mainly on side and back sleeper support, durability, and stability; displayed score is out of a total of 100 points.
models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: This foam mattress does a fine job for most sleepers: Petite and average-sized sleepers should enjoy Very Good support no matter their sleep position (side or back), though in CR’s tests the mattress delivered just average support for all types of large/tall sleepers. This model’s durability is first-rate, but stability is just so-so. And it doesn’t make changing sleep positions as easy as it could be.

models.modelName: Alexander Signature Hybrid Copper Infused Thermic Phase Change Cooling Fabric
models.overallScoreDescription: Based mainly on side and back sleeper support, durability, and stability; displayed score is out of a total of 100 points.
models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: Combining coils with layers of foam, this mattress-in-a-box excels in some areas and falls short in others. It’s highly stable, and durability is top-notch. But back and side support is spotty: very good for petite sleepers and average-sized side sleepers, and so-so for everyone else. With a firmness rating of 2 out of 10, this model is very soft. The 14-inch height means deep-pocket fitted sheets may be needed.

models.overallScoreDescription: Based mainly on side and back sleeper support, durability, and stability; displayed score is out of a total of 100 points.
models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: Boasting natural and organic materials, this hybrid of coils and latex foam is extremely durable. But that’s about the best you can say about this mattress-in-a-box. The back and side support for all sizes and styles of sleepers is no better than average. And it does just a good job at minimizing how much vibrations travel across the mattress, which could be a problem for couples.

models.overallScoreDescription: Based mainly on side and back sleeper support, durability, and stability; displayed score is out of a total of 100 points.
models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: This reasonably priced foam mattress stands up to the competition in several key areas: In CR’s durability and stability tests, the model received Excellent ratings. Sleepers should be able to move with ease without bothering a partner. Support, though, is mixed: Very Good for all back sleepers and petite side sleepers, but average and large and tall side sleepers will have to make do with so-so support. CR's tests found that the mattress retains heat.

expertReview.bottomLine: This reasonably priced foam mattress-in-a-box is a strong performer all-around. Back and side sleepers of every size, from petites to tall folks, can expect very good support. Top-notch durability means softening, sagging, and other damage shouldn’t be a problem. It’s highly stable, so the vibrations from a partner’s tossing and turning shouldn’t travel far. And it’s resilient enough to let sleepers change positions easily.

expertReview.bottomLine: In the crowded field of bed-in-a-box foam mattresses, this model is midpack: no glaring flaws, but not top of the class either. The support is mixed: Excellent for petite back sleepers, Very Good for average back sleepers and petite side sleepers, and so-so for the rest. It’s durable, but stability is just average, and the mattress does not make it easy to shift positions.

expertReview.bottomLine: For its high price, this foam mattresses offers up only organic materials, including natural rubber latex. But unless you’re petite and rest on your back, the support may disappoint: In CR’s tests, support was merely Good for all other sizes and types of sleepers. The durability is Excellent, with no discernible sagging, softening, or damage during eight years of simulated use. The surface is more breathable than others, potentially reducing perspiration.

expertReview.bottomLine: Back sleepers should be able to get behind this foam-topped innerspring mattress: In CR’s tests, their support is rated Very Good or better, depending on your size. But side sleepers may be disappointed in the middling support they get. And the stability is no better than average. Durability is first-rate, though, with no noticeable changes in performance in eight years of simulated use.

expertReview.bottomLine: This relatively expensive organic foam mattress fails to impress on most CR tests. For side sleepers and petite back sleepers, support is Very Good, but that’s where the high marks end. Stability, durability, and support for other back sleepers are all no better than average. This model is not compatible with bed frames that allow you to raise and lower the head and foot section independently. With a firmness rating of 8 out of 10, this ranks among the firmest foam models.

expertReview.bottomLine: The verdict on this air-adjustable mattress depends on the size of the sleeper. Petite and average-sized ones can expect support that's rated Very Good, but large and tall sleepers can find better support in other air-adjustable mattresses. This model is highly durable, but stability is just average. That means vibrations may travel across the bed. And it doesn’t make it easy for sleepers to shift positions.

models.overallScoreDescription: Based mainly on side and back sleeper support, durability, and stability; displayed score is out of a total of 100 points.
models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: This latex-foam mattress boasts excellent durability: Over eight years of simulated use, there was no noticeable sagging, softening, or other damage. The stability is top-notch too, so vibrations from one partner’s tossing and turning shouldn’t travel far across the mattress. It’s resilient enough to make changing sleep positions easy. Back and side support, though, is mixed: very good for petite and average-sized back sleepers, and average for everyone else.

expertReview.bottomLine: Purple’s signature feature is a thick, grid-like cushioning layer atop the coils, and the result in CR’s tests is a mattress that delivers Very Good support for most sleepers (large/tall back sleepers, though, have to settle with so-so support). The mattress is highly stable and top-of-the-class when it comes to durability, with little sagging, softening, or damage after eight years of simulated use.

expertReview.bottomLine: With a score of 3 out of 10 in CR’s firmness tests, this model—which features a unique honeycomb structure—is among the softer foam mattresses. Petite to average side and back sleepers will get impressive support, but for large and tall sleepers of all styles the support is merely Good, middle-of-the-pack. Still, The Purple Bed is highly stable, resisting bounciness and allowing for easy changes in position. And the durability is top-notch.

models.modelName: Scott Living by Restonic Cascade Eurotop
models.overallScoreDescription: Based mainly on side and back sleeper support, durability, and stability; displayed score is out of a total of 100 points.
models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: This innerspring and foam mattress is highly durable but overall fails to impress. Support for petite and average-sized side sleepers is rated Very Good. No so for back sleepers: Support is subpar for large/tall ones and merely average for smaller folks. With a 2-out-of-10 firmness rating, it’s very soft, and stability is merely average. The 16-inch height means deep-pocket fitted sheets are a must.

models.modelName: Dream Supreme II Hybrid Sleep System Medium
models.overallScoreDescription: Based mainly on side and back sleeper support, durability, and stability; displayed score is out of a total of 100 points.
models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: With this high-end Reverie mattress, you get the brand’s customizable support system: Scores of foam springs of varying densities can be repositioned in countless configurations to suit you and your partner. The upshot? In the medium configuration, it delivers Very Good support for side sleepers and okay support for most back sleepers. The durability is first-rate, with no noticeable change in performance over eight years of simulated use, and the mattress is highly stable.

models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: This high-end mattress has 204 foam cylinders of varying densities that can be arranged into countless configurations. (The manufacturer provides instructions on how to place them to create a mattress that’s firm, medium, or soft.) In the firm configuration, the result is Very Good or Excellent support for all types and sizes of sleepers. It receives an Excellent score for durability and is highly stable. Unlike many other top foam mattresses, it has grips to make handling easier.

models.modelName: Dream Supreme II Hybrid Sleep System Soft
models.overallScoreDescription: Based mainly on side and back sleeper support, durability, and stability; displayed score is out of a total of 100 points.
models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: With this high-end Reverie mattress, you get the brand’s customizable support system: Scores of foam springs of varying densities can be repositioned in countless configurations. The soft configuration, however, lags its “firm” and “medium” configurations overall (even though in CR’s tests the firmness is similar: 3 out of 10 for this model vs. 4 for the firm model). Like the other two, the durability is Excellent and the stability is top-notch, and support is rated Very Good for side sleepers. But back sleepers will do better elsewhere.

models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: Back sleepers should be well served by this low-priced foam mattress-in-a-box. Support for them is rated Very Good. All but petite side sleepers, though, will find support that’s no better than average. On the plus side, this model is highly durable, but stability is so-so, which could mean mattress-wide vibrations when a sleeping partner moves around. Plus, it doesn’t make it easy to shift positions.

expertReview.bottomLine: Unlike many foam mattresses, this model doesn’t come stuffed in a box. But that's about it for standing out from the pack. On the bright side, it’s highly durable, and the support is rated Very Good for back sleepers of all sizes. But side sleepers aren’t well served by this model. The stability is just average, so vibrations may travel across the bed, and it doesn’t make shifting positions easy.

models.overallScoreDescription: Based mainly on side and back sleeper support, durability, and stability; displayed score is out of a total of 100 points.
models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: Most sleepers will enjoy Very Good support with this innerspring model (petite side sleepers and large/tall back sleepers are the exceptions). It gets top ratings for durability, with no discernible sagging, softening, or damage after eight years of simulated use, but stability is merely average. The brand’s signature dual layers of coils mean this model comes in at 16 inches high, so you’ll need deep-pocket fitted sheets.

expertReview.bottomLine: Made with all-natural latex foam, this model delivers mixed results when it comes to support. Back sleepers can expect impressive support, but for most side sleepers it’s no better than average. Durability is rated Excellent, with no discernible softening, sagging, or damage in eight years of simulated use. Unlike many foam models, it doesn't retain body heat, which can make sleepers feel warm. Stability is so-so.

models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: This mattress-in-a-box combines innersprings with layers of foam with mixed results. Support for petite sleepers and average-sized back sleepers is rated Very Good. For the rest, it’s no better than average. On the plus side, durability is first-rate, and it’s highly stable. A firmness rating of 3 out of 10 puts this model on the soft side. Just 11 inches high, there’s no need for deep-pocket fitted sheets.

expertReview.bottomLine: This innerspring mattress topped with gel-infused foam is well-priced, but that doesn’t make it a steal. The back and spine support for almost every type of sleeper is no better than average. On the plus side, the mattress does a fine job at muting vibrations that can travel across the bed, and it’s highly durable. At 14 inches high, it may require deep-pocket fitted sheets.

expertReview.bottomLine: The price of this lightweight innerspring may attract bargain hunters, but some notable flaws should give them pause. The biggest: In CR’s tests, this bouncy mattress lets a significant amount of vibrations travel across the bed, earning it a Poor rating for stability. For many sleepers, the support is so-so (petite and average-sized back sleepers do better). On the plus side, the durability is better than average.

expertReview.bottomLine: Petite sleepers do well with this innerspring mattress topped with memory foam, but most others can find more back and spine support elsewhere. On the plus side, the mattress is highly stable, limiting how much vibrations go from one part of the bed to another, and it rates Excellent for durability, with little in the way of sagging, softening, or damage after eight years of simulated use.

expertReview.bottomLine: When it comes to back and side support, the verdict on this reasonably priced mattress is mixed. Petite sleepers are well-served. For those who are average-sized or large and tall, support is very good if they sleep on their backs but just so-so if they rest on their sides. Still, in CR’s tests this model was found to be highly stable, and the durability is top-notch.

expertReview.bottomLine: For petite and average-sized back sleepers, the support offered by this Sealy model is second to none. And side sleepers and large and tall back sleepers don’t have much to complain about either. In CR’s test, durability was found to be Excellent. Stability, however, is merely Good, and the mattress doesn’t allow for easy shifting around. The mattress retains warmth, which keeps you toasty in winter but may not be ideal in warmer months.

expertReview.bottomLine: For nearly every type of sleeper, this innerspring and foam mattress delivers impressive support. The exception: large and tall back sleepers, for whom support is so-so. Durability is rated Excellent: no noticeable changes in performance over eight years of simulated use. But its stability is just average, so sleepers may feel a partner’s tossing and turning. And this model doesn’t make switching sleeping positions easy.

expertReview.bottomLine: This tall innerspring mattress topped with gel-infused foam should please back sleepers: In CR's tests, their support was rated Very Good, even Excellent for petite people. But the support for side sleepers of all sizes was middle-of-the-road. The mattress is extremely durable, holding up well after eight years of simulated use. And it’s highly stable, keeping vibrations down and resisting bounciness.

expertReview.bottomLine: This innerspring mattress topped with memory foam supports most sleepers well. Support for petite back sleepers in particular is top-notch, though large/tall side sleepers will experience only so-so support. It’s rated Excellent for durability. Stability, however, was found to be no better than average, and the mattress doesn’t allow for easy shifts in position. Scoring a 3 out of 10 for firmness, it’s on the soft side.

models.modelName: Posturepedic Shore Drive LTD Extra Firm
models.overallScoreDescription: Based mainly on side and back sleeper support, durability, and stability; displayed score is out of a total of 100 points.
models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: This highly durable innerspring mattress is a solid choice for back sleepers. The support they can expect ranges from very good to excellent. But for side sleepers of all sizes, the support is no better than average. Plus, stability is average too, raising the chances that one sleeper will feel a partner’s tossing and turning. True to the name, this mattress earns a high 7 out of 10 for firmness.

expertReview.bottomLine: With a firmness rating of 2 out of 10, this foam mattress is distinctly soft. Support is Very Good for side sleepers. For back sleepers, it’s a different story: so-so support for most (and below average for the large and tall). The durability is first-rate, with only minor changes in performance over eight years of simulated use. This mattress retains heat, which can make sleepers feel warmer.

models.modelName: Response Performance Beech Street Eurotop Cushion Firm
models.overallScoreDescription: Based mainly on side and back sleeper support, durability, and stability; displayed score is out of a total of 100 points.
models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: With this moderately priced innerspring mattress, the bottom line depends on your preferred sleep position. Back sleepers should be pleased with the support it provides, but for side sleepers, the spine support is no better than average. Still, this mattress is highly stable, a plus for couples. And its durability earns an Excellent rating. Sagging, softening, and other damage shouldn’t be a major problem in the years ahead.

models.modelName: Response Performance Chestnut Street Cushion Firm
models.overallScoreDescription: Based mainly on side and back sleeper support, durability, and stability; displayed score is out of a total of 100 points.
models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: This reasonably priced innerspring model provides impressive support for back sleepers. For all but petite side sleepers, though, the spine support is no better than average. Still, its durability earns an Excellent rating, with little sagging, softening, and other damage over eight years of simulated use. Plus, it’s highly stable, a notable feature for sleepers hoping to keep vibrations from a partner’s jostling from traveling across the bed’s surface.

expertReview.bottomLine: When it comes to the all-important task of providing side and back support, this reasonably priced mattress-in-a-box fails to impress. For all except petite sleepers, support is no better than average. A firmness rating of 1 out of 10 means this model is quite soft. And with a so-so rating for stability, one sleeper may feel a partner’s jostling. On the plus side, durability is excellent.

expertReview.bottomLine: This model delivers Very Good support for all side sleepers, but back sleepers can do better elsewhere. The durability is first-rate, with little in the way of sagging, softening, or damage after eight years of simulated use. But the stability is only so-so, and it is not compatible with bed frames that allow you to adjust the head and foot sections independently. With a firmness rating of 3 out of 10, it’s on the soft side.

models.overallScoreDescription: Based mainly on side and back sleeper support, durability, and stability; displayed score is out of a total of 100 points.
models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: Topped by layers of foam, this innerspring mattress boasts first-rate durability and impressive stability, but the support is inconsistent. It delivers Very Good spine support to petite and average-sized side sleepers. For all other types of sleepers, the support is mediocre. The mattress tends to trap warmth, which can make a sleeper feel warmer. With a height of 14 inches, it may need deep-pocket fitted sheets.

attributes.name: Petite side sleeper
attributes.description: Sleepers small in both height and weight.

attributes.name: Average side sleeper
attributes.description: An average of both the petite and large scores that applies to many people.

attributes.name: Type
attributes.description: Indicates the main composition of the mattress, such as innerspring or memory foam. Some so-called "hybrid" innersprings include one or more levels of foam on top.

attributes.name: Dimensions LxWxH
attributes.description: The mattress's dimensions, length by width by height, in inches.

attributes.name: Latex foam
attributes.description: An alternative to memory foam.

attributes.name: Gel-infused foam
attributes.description: A layer of foam infused with gel, which is claimed to make you feel cooler in bed, especially with memory foam.

attributes.name: Resists bounciness
attributes.description: Indicates whether the mattress can absorb impacts, minimizing the bouncy feeling you might encounter while changing sleep position.

attributes.name: Eases movement
attributes.description: Indicates whether the mattress has enough resilience to allow easy changes in sleep position.

attributes.name: Grips
attributes.description: Helpful when handling the mattress.

attributes.name: Retains warmth
attributes.description: Some mattresses are more insulating than others and trap body heat, making you feel warmer.

attributes.name: Large/Tall side sleeper
attributes.description: Side sleepers who are above 6 ft 2 inches tall and/or 220 pounds.

attributes.name: Petite back sleeper
attributes.description: Sleepers small in both height and weight.

attributes.name: Average back sleeper
attributes.description: An average of both the petite and large scores that applies to many people.

attributes.name: Large/Tall back sleeper
attributes.description: Back sleepers who are above 6 ft 2 inches tall, and/or 220 pounds.

attributes.name: Durability
attributes.description: Our analysis of how well a mattress maintains its original shape, height, firmness, and side/back sleeping support after 8 years of simulated use.

attributes.name: Stabilization
attributes.description: A measure of how much vibration is transmitted across the mattress; for memory- and latex-foam mattresses, higher scores indicate ease of changing sleep position.

attributes.name: Firmness rating
attributes.description: Indicates how firm a mattress is on our scale from 1 to 10, where 1 is very soft and 10 is very firm.

attributes.name: Adjustable frame
attributes.description: Adjustable bed frames will allow the head and foot sections to be raised and lowered independently. Note: Some manufacturer's beds will only be compatible with their own adjustable bed frames.

attributes.name: Mattress-in-a-box
attributes.description: The mattress will be delivered to your door compressed and rolled into a box to make it more manageable. Some boxes will be approximately 42 inches tall, 20 inches wide and 20 inches deep and can weigh between 60 and 120 pounds.

models.overallScoreDescription: Based mainly on side and back sleeper support, durability, and stability; displayed score is out of a total of 100 points.
models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: This firm foam mattress-in-a-box comes through for back sleepers, providing very good support, but most side sleepers can do better elsewhere. The durability is first-rate, with no discernible changes in performance over eight years of simulated use. This model is highly stable, but sleepers may find that shifting positions is hard. Unlike many foam mattresses, it doesn’t tend to trap body heat and make sleepers feel warm.

models.modelName: Perfect Sleeper Hybrid Standale II Luxury
models.overallScoreDescription: Based mainly on side and back sleeper support, durability, and stability; displayed score is out of a total of 100 points.
models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: With innersprings topped with gel-infused foam, this model performs well across the board. The support is very good for almost every sleeper. (For large and tall side sleepers, it’s merely average.) Durability is top-notch, and the mattress is highly stable, which minimizes how far vibrations travel. This model retains heat, which can make a sleeper feel warmer. The 14-inch height means deep-pocket fitted sheets may be needed.

expertReview.bottomLine: Anyone who happens to be petite may be pleased with this well-priced foam-topped innerspring mattress: Their support is rated Very Good. But everyone else can find better support elsewhere. The durability is top-notch, and the mattress does a fine job at muting vibrations. It also retains body heat, which can make sleepers feel warmer. At 15 inches high, it will require deep-pocket fitted sheets.

expertReview.bottomLine: This foam mattress-in-a-box should please people of all sizes and sleeping styles. Support for back and side sleepers is impressive, with petite back sleepers especially well served. Durability is rated Excellent, with no noticeable sagging, softening, or damage in eight years of simulated use. With just so-so stability, though, sleepers may feel vibrations when a partner moves, and this model doesn’t make it easy to shift positions.

expertReview.bottomLine: Whether or not this reasonably priced foam mattress makes the grade depends on sleeper size and style. Support is rated Excellent for petite and average-sized back sleepers, and is nearly as impressive for most side sleepers. But for large and tall side sleepers, it’s no better than average. Durability is first-rate, but stability can be a problem. This model does a below-average job of minimizing vibrations, and shifting sleep positions isn’t easy.

models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: This top-notch air-adjustable mattress is reasonably priced for the category. Support is impressive across the board, even rated Excellent for most back sleepers. Durability is superb, with no discernible changes in performance over eight years of simulated use. It’s highly stable, so one sleeper’s nocturnal movements shouldn’t bother a partner. Plus, this model adds a layer of gel-infused foam.

expertReview.bottomLine: When it comes to providing sleepers with adequate support, this adjustable-air model fails to impress. For all types of sleepers, the support is no better than average. On the plus side, durability is rated Excellent, with no noticeable sagging, softening, or damage in eight years of simulated use. This mattress is highly stable, too, minimizing how much vibrations travel across the bed. And shifting sleep positions shouldn’t be a problem.

expertReview.bottomLine: This memory foam, adjustable-air model is pricey, but overall it delivers first-rate performance. In CR’s tests, the mattress scores Very Good ratings for its support of side and back sleepers of all sizes. The durability is hard to beat. And as with other Sleep Number mattresses we've tested, both partners can adjust the firmness of independent halves of the bed.

models.overallScoreDescription: Based mainly on side and back sleeper support, durability, and stability; displayed score is out of a total of 100 points.
models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: This bed-in-a-box delivers top performance at a reasonable price. Back sleepers can expect Excellent support, and side sleepers shouldn’t be disappointed either. The green materials—natural latex foam and organic cotton and wool—hold up well in durability testing. The mattress tends to trap body heat, making the sleeper feel warmer. And with a score of 7 out of 10 in CR’s firmness test, the “firm” in the name is spot-on.

models.overallScoreDescription: Based mainly on side and back sleeper support, durability, and stability; displayed score is out of a total of 100 points.
models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: Back sleepers can rest easy with this latex foam mattress-in-a-box: The support it provides is first-rate. For all except petite side sleepers, though, side support is merely average. The durability earns an Excellent rating, with little sagging, softening, and other damage over eight years of simulated use. Stability is no better than average, so sleepers may feel vibrations from a partner’s nocturnal shifts.

expertReview.bottomLine: Sleepers who prefer to lie on their backs shouldn’t be disappointed with this budget mattress-in-a-box: For that group, the support is very good. But all except petite side sleepers will find just average spine support. This model is durable and stable, but it doesn’t make shifting positions easy, and like many foam mattresses, it retains body heat, which can make sleepers feel warm.

models.overallScoreDescription: Based mainly on side and back sleeper support, durability, and stability; displayed score is out of a total of 100 points.
models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: This well-priced innerspring mattress excels in few areas. The durability is Excellent, but top-notch performance pretty much ends there. The support for back sleepers ranges from so-so to below average. Among side sleepers, only large/tall ones can expect decent support. And the stability is mediocre, which could mean the vibrations from one sleeper’s tossing and turning travel from one side of the bed to the other.

models.overallScoreDescription: Based mainly on side and back sleeper support, durability, and stability; displayed score is out of a total of 100 points.
models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: Almost all sleepers can expect Very Good support with this innerspring. The exception: large/tall back sleepers, for whom support is a disappointing Fair. The durability is first-rate, with only minor changes in performance after eight years of simulated use. But it does just a so-so job at keeping down vibrations, important for couples. It measures about 14 inches, so you might need deep-pocket fitted sheets.

models.modelName: Estate Hurston 14" Cushion firm tight top
models.overallScoreDescription: Based mainly on side and back sleeper support, durability, and stability; displayed score is out of a total of 100 points.
models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: Most sleepers can look forward to impressive support from this innerspring mattress topped with gel-infused foam. (For large and tall back sleepers, support is merely average.) The durability is top-notch, with little in the way of sagging, softening, or other damage over eight years of simulated use. But stability is no better than average, so couples may find that vibrations from a partner’s movements travel across the bed.

models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: Back sleepers should do fine with this innerspring model. But all but petite side sleepers, who can expect merely average support, may be disappointed. Stability is another problem spot. A so-so rating of Good means the mattress doesn’t excel at minimizing vibrations. With a 14-inch height, deep-pocket fitted sheets may be called for. Still, durability is rated Excellent. A layer of gel-infused foam may help keep sleepers cool.

models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: Anyone who sleeps on their side should be pleased with the fine support they get from this innerspring and memory foam mattress. For most back sleepers, though, the support is no better than average. With a firmness rating of 2 out of 10, this model is soft, and it doesn’t make shifting sleep positions easy. Still, durability is excellent. The 14-inch height means deep-pocket fitted sheets may be needed.

models.overallScoreDescription: Based mainly on side and back sleeper support, durability, and stability; displayed score is out of a total of 100 points.
models.priceDescription: Approximate retail for a queen-size mattresses without box spring (roughly $150 to $300).

expertReview.bottomLine: On most measures, this mattress fails to break out of the pack. For nearly every type and size of sleeper, back and spine support is no better than average. While durability is rated Excellent, stability is so-so, raising the chance that sleepers will feel a partner’s jostling. And it’s not resilient enough to allow for easy changes in position. At just 11 inches high, there’s no need for deep-pocket fitted sheets.

expertReview.bottomLine: With this high-end foam mattress, it pays to be petite: Those sleepers will enjoy very good back and side support. For all others, the support fails to impress. This model’s durability is first-rate, with no noticeable changes in performance over eight years of simulated use. Stability, though, is merely average, and it’s not easy to shift positions. A firmness rating of 3 out of 10 puts it on the soft side.

expertReview.bottomLine: The best feature of this foam mattress is its durability. In eight years of simulated use, it shows no sign of sagging, softening, or damage. Plus, petite side sleepers can expect support that's rated Very Good. But support for all other sleepers is no better than average. Stability is so-so too, leaving sleepers at risk of feeling every vibration. With a firmness rating of 2 out of 10, it’s on the soft side.

expertReview.bottomLine: Back sleepers can rest easy with this durable foam model, thanks to support that earns an Excellent rating. For most side sleepers, though, spine support is no better than average. The mattress’s stability is also middling, so vibrations from a fellow sleeper’s shifts may travel. Like many foam models, it doesn’t make shifting positions easy. With a firmness rating of 7 out of 10, it delivers on the promise in the name.

expertReview.bottomLine: This high-end hybrid mattress boasts first-rate durability, but the top-level performance pretty much ends there. Spine and back support is no better than average, no matter the size of the sleeper. Worse, this model earns a Fair rating for stability, so it does a below-average job of minimizing vibrations. It doesn’t make shifting sleep positions easy. With a firmness rating of 2 out of 10, it’s especially soft.

expertReview.bottomLine: Both The Original Mattress Factory store and brand are highly rated in CR subscriber satisfaction surveys. This innerspring does well in CR’s tests but doesn’t rise to the top. Most sleepers should see Very Good support, though large/tall back sleepers might be less satisfied. The mattress sagged a bit in durability tests and relayed some bounce across the bed. It measures 14 inches, so you'll probably need deep-pocket fitted sheets.

expertReview.bottomLine: In a satisfaction survey of CR subscribers, The Original Mattress Factory store ranks among the favorites, earning an Excellent score for service. Its latex foam mattress, though, doesn’t do as well in CR’s tests. The support is Very Good for side sleepers, but so-so if you prefer lying on your back. Durability is first-rate, with only minor changes in performance over eight years of simulated use. Stability is average.

expertReview.bottomLine: This foam and innerspring mattress-in-a-box performs decently but fails to break out of the pack. It serves side sleepers well, offering Very Good spine support. But back sleepers can do better elsewhere. It’s highly stable and durable, with only minor changes in firmness, support, height, and shape over eight years of simulated use. In CR’s tests, it was found to retain heat, which can make sleepers feel warm.

expertReview.bottomLine: This reasonably priced foam mattress has the potential to be a crowd pleaser: In CR’s tests, it receives Very Good support scores for every type of sleeper: back or side, petite to tall. And it gets top marks for durability and stability, so one sleeper’s nocturnal shifts shouldn’t bother a partner. In a satisfaction survey of CR subscribers, the Tuft & Needle brand lands near the top.

expertReview.bottomLine: This well-priced foam mattress hails from Tuft & Needle, the brand that's highly rated in a satisfaction survey of CR’s subscribers. This model offers plenty to like, especially for side sleepers, who should enjoy Very Good support. Durability is outstanding, with only minor changes in performance after eight years of simulated use, stability is top-notch, and changing positions is no problem. CR's tests found it to be very breathable, important for shoppers who feel that foam beds "sleep hot."

expertReview.bottomLine: This gel-infused memory foam mattress excels in some ways and falls short in others. The durability is top-notch: only minor deterioration after eight years of simulated use. It does a fine job of muting vibrations when a sleep partner moves. Where it really counts, though, the results are mixed. Though the support for petite sleepers and average-sized side sleepers is Very Good, it’s midpack for everyone else.

expertReview.bottomLine: This affordable foam mattress-in-a-box may disappoint side sleepers, who can expect no better than average spine support. Only petite and average-sized back sleepers will enjoy support, which is rated Very Good for them. This model is durable, but not as durable as other top foam mattresses. It’s highly stable, minimizing how much movements travel across the bed. Still, it doesn’t make shifting sleeping positions easy. It also tends to retain body heat.
